text.b: An FPGA-based Scalable Simulation Accelerator for Tile

page.text: Shinya Takamaeda-Yamazaki
, Ryosuke Sasakawa
, Yoshito Sakaguchi
, Kenji Kise
Graduate School of Information Science and Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology
JSPS Research Fellow
{takamaeda, sasakawa, yoshito}@arch.cs.titech.ac.jp, kise@cs.titech.ac.jp
ABSTRACT
FPGA-based simulation systems can simulate processor be-
havior in realistic time. In order to practically simulate tile
many-core architectures, we propose ScalableCore for pro-
totyping system development using multiple FPGAs. In this
paper, we present an FPGA-based platform called ScalableCore
system 1.1, which consists of several simulation tiles named
ScalableCore Units. Each tile is connected to four neighbor
tiles via interface boards called ScalableCore Boards, and so
increasing the target number of cores is easy. We also de-
scribe useful techniques by which to achieve high scalability
of simulation and to implement complicated hardware func-
tions on an FPGA. The developed system simulates the be-
havior of a tile architecture with DMA communications and
NoC 14.2 times faster than a corresponding software-based
functional simulator running on a standard computer with an
Intel Core2Duo processor. We veriÔ¨Åed that the ScalableCore
system is cycle-accurate by comparing the simulation behav-
ior on a software-based simulator.
Keywords
Multi-FPGA System; Processor Prototyping; Tile Archi-
tecture
INTRODUCTION
Various processor simulators have been widely used to eval-
uate novel architectures and techniques in the computer ar-
chitecture research area. Popular software-based simulators,
such as SimpleScalar [1], GEMS [2], and M5 [3], are cus-
tomizable and operate on computers such as inexpensive per-
sonal computers and high-end workstations and so are used
in various studies. However, these software-based simula-
tors perform simulation far slower than simulated proces-
sors. In order to evaluate the proposed method under more
realistic conditions, today‚Äôs computer research requires faster
simulation environments.
The processor trend is moving toward many-core proces-
sors for power-efÔ¨Åcient, high-performance computing. In
order to efÔ¨Åciently realize an emerging many-core processor,
efÔ¨Åcient evaluation environments are needed. Moreover, in
order to handle an increasing number of cores, the simula-
tion speed and scalability of the simulation environment are
very important. FPGA-based simulation systems are used
to accelerate simulation. However, previous systems either
cannot increase the target number of cores or have no scal-
ability of the simulation speed, which would enable system
to handle a large number of cores.
A simple and honest solution that would enable a large
number of cores to be handled is to use distributed envi-
ronments, such as multi-FPGA systems. However, in the
multi-FPGA system, maintaining the simulation speed for
an increasing number of cores is difÔ¨Åcult because (1) efÔ¨Å-
cient and scalable synchronization of simulation informa-
tion among FPGAs is required for fast cycle-accurate simu-
lation, (2) FPGA systems have hardware limitations in terms
of memory ports, memory size, or CAM complexity, and (3)
many FPGAs require scalable power supplies. These prob-
lems must be overcome in order to create a scalable environ-
ment.
We present ScalableCore [4], which is a concept based upon
which to develop a many-core processor emulator using mul-
tiple FPGAs with scalability. We describe useful techniques
to solve the above described problems. This paper also intro-
duces a multi-FPGA-based simulator, called ScalableCore
system 1.1, for tile architectures. The system consists of
many simulation tiles called ScalableCore Units. Each tile
consists of low-end small FPGAs (Xilinx Spartan-3E
XC3S500E) and is connected to four adjacent tiles, so it is
easy to increase the core count in the simulated architecture
while maintaining the simulation speed.
The ScalableCore system 1.1 simulates the behavior of a
simple processor consisting of 64 nodes 14.2 times faster
than a corresponding software-based functional simulator run-
ning on a standard computer with an Intel Core2Duo Pro-
cessor. Note that the implementation of the processor core
on the software simulator is equivalent to a functional-level
processor core. Therefore, the simulation speed will be de-
graded in simulations of more detailed processor cores, and
the speedup of the ScalableCore system will be increased.
System validation is important for reliable simulation re-
sults. In order to conÔ¨Årm that the ScalableCore system is
cycle-accurate, we veriÔ¨Åed that the behavior of the Scal-
ableCore system is equivalent to the behavior of the corre-
sponding software simulator by comparing their processor
core state and network state for each cycle in the target pro-
cessor.
The major contributions of this paper are:
‚Ä¢ ScalableCore, which is a concept based upon which to
develop large-scale prototyping systems using a num-
ber of small FPGAs while maintaining the scalability
of the simulation speed in a multi-FPGAs system.
‚Ä¢ We describe a technique by which to easily implement
complex and unsuitable hardware on FPGAs.
‚Ä¢ We demonstrate that the simulation speed of this sys-
tem is scalable and is 14.2 times faster than the corre-
sponding software simulator in the case of simulation
using 64 cores.

is equivalent to that of software simulator at the cycle

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Sec-
tion 2 presents related works. Section 3 describes the Scal-
ableCore, which is a concept based upon which to realize a
scalable emulator, as well as techniques by which to achieve
scalability and to easily implement target hardware func-
tions. In addition, this section describes the actual imple-
mentation issues of ScalableCore system 1.1, which is a sys-
tem with connected 64 FPGA tiles. In Section 4, we evalu-
ate the implemented system with respect to simulation speed
and system accuracy. Finally, Section 5 presents a summary
of this paper.
RELATED WORK
There have been several studies on the simulation environ-
ment for multicore processors and many-core processors. In
order to efÔ¨Åciently execute a parallel program on multicore
or many-core processors, we must carefully consider not
only processor architectures but also middleware and run-
time software behavior. Therefore, a fast simulation envi-
ronment for multicore and many-core processors is very im-
portant.
RAMP Gold [5, 6], which uses a single moderately sized
FPGA, is an attempt to quickly simulate a many-core proces-
sor with 64 cores and shared caches with a crossbar network.
In RAMP Gold, the functional model and the timing model
of the target processor are implemented separately. In order
to efÔ¨Åciently simulate a large number of cores with respect
to time, RAMP Gold uses host-multithreading, i.e., running
multiple threads simulating different target cores on a single
simulating tile, which reduces the memory access overhead
and the circuit overhead of data forwarding.
Most other studies [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12] use a single FPGA
or a small number of large FPGAs to implement the entire
processor. This makes the system extremely fast. However,
it may limit the core count to be simulated and may reduce
the simulation speed as the core count increases. In addition,
systems with large FPGAs greatly increase the compiling
time required to generate a bit stream.
We adopt the other method of using a number of small FP-
GAs and develop a simulator with scalable simulation speed
as the core count increases.
PROPOSAL OF THE SCALABLECORE
SYSTEM
Concept
We herein propose ScalableCore, which is a concept based
upon which to develop a scalable environment for tile archi-
tecture simulation. Using multiple distributed FPGAs, the
system forms an emulator. Figure.1 shows the concept of
the ScalableCore. In the following, we referred to a system
based on this concept as a ScalableCore system.
The ScalableCore system consists of both the simulation
tiles and connection interfaces of these nodes, referred to
herein as ScalableCore Units and ScalableCore Boards,
respectively. The ScalableCore Unit is a small custom de-
signed FPGA board. Each ScalableCore Unit corresponds
to a processor core in the target tile architecture and has
emulated functions in the target processor core. Each Scal-
ableCore Unit can communicate with adjacent ScalableCore
Units by serial I/O via the signal wires on ScalableCore Boards.
Figure 1: ScalableCore concept. An example for a 4
FPGAs ScalableCore system.
We can change the number of ScalableCore Units that make
up the system. In the case of a 4
√ó 4, 16-core processor,
√ó 4) ScalableCore Units and 25 (5 √ó 5) ScalableCore
Boards to connect the ScalableCore Units are required. Each
ScalableCore Unit is connected to only four adjacent Scal-
ableCore Units, and each unit can directly communicate with
only adjacent units. For hardware scalability, ScalableCore
Units do not have global signal lines.
In order to emulate complex functions which are not suit-
able for direct implementation onto FPGAs, such as a multi-
port RAM, the system emulates the target behavior in one
clock cycle using multiple FPGA clocks. We refer to this as
the Virtual Cycle.
In order to obtain cycle-accurate simulation results, each
ScalableCore Unit must know the newest simulation infor-
mation, such as the state of on-chip routers and the state of
processor cores, generated by the others must be used. This
can be achieved simply by using an all-to-all barrier, and
states are updated during each cycle on the target processor
for the entire system. However, all-to-all operations have a
very large overhead and make the system non-scalable.
Since the ScalableCore system focuses on tile architectures
consisting of a mesh network, sharing of simulation informa-
tion among all FPGAs is not necessary. In order to satisfy the
cycle accuracy, each ScalableCore Unit must share informa-
tion among only its four adjacent ScalableCore Units. We
refer to this bound-reduced simulation information sharing
as Local Barrier Synchronization. This technique enables
the number of ScalableCore Units used for simulation can be
increased without increasing the synchronization overhead,
which allows a scalable simulation speed.
The program image for each unit is stored in an SD card,
which is shown as a black rectangle. When the system ini-
tiates the simulation, the top-left unit ((1,1) in the Ô¨Ågure)
distributes the program image to every unit. A custom com-
mand interpreter type display enables the simulating state to
be visualized.
System Architecture
Each ScalableCore Unit has the functions of the target pro-
cessor as well as some system level functions. Figure.2 shows
the function hierarchy of a ScalableCore Unit. Figure.3 shows
the function architecture of each ScalableCore Unit. All
of the function units are described in Verilog HDL, which

comprises approximately 8,000 lines of code. There are
four main layers of the function implementation, namely, the
physical layer, link layer, base system layer, and user layer.
The physical layer, link layer, and base system layer pro-
vide the system functions to construct the target processor‚Äôs
functions and to control the simulation state by local barrier
synchronization.
The target architecture of ScalableCore System 1.1 is an M-
Core architecture [13], which consists of multiple computa-
tion units connected by a mesh NoC. The Computation Node
in Figure.2 corresponds to a tile in a processor. The Com-
putation Node has a core, which is an execution unit, a node
memory, which is a local memory with a independent mem-
ory address space, an on-chip router, and an INCC, which is
an network interface dealing network packets to/from NoC.
In this version, the ScalableCore system has no off-chip
memory functions. This will be investigated in the future.
Here, we introduce the Virtual Cycle. A Virtual Cycle cor-
responds to a clock cycle of the target processor and com-
prises several FPGA clock cycles. The goal is to emulate
rich hardware mechanisms, which are unsuitable for FPGAs,
such as multiple RAM port. Therefore, the target behavior is
emulated in a time interleaved fashion by operating a simple
hardware unit multiple times. This reduces the implementa-
tion complexity.
Figure.4 shows a time chart of ScalableCore system 1.1.
Each block indicates the period during which the correspond-
ing function unit is working. The Computation Node in
M-Core architecture requires 32-bits and four RAM ports
(I-Fetch, Load/Store, Network Interface Read, and Network
Figure 4: Virtual Cycle.
Interface Write) for node memory. However, an SRAM on
each ScalableCore Unit in this version has only one port for
8-bit read/write operation. Therefore, the memory access
behavior on INCC and Core is emulated by accessing the
SRAM 16 times. At the same time, the system drives the
functions of emulated hardware for combinational circuits
and Ô¨Çip-Ô¨Çops, and each unit shares simulation information
with its neighbors, which reduces emulation and synchro-
nization overhead.
Here, we describe the rolls of each layer.
Physical Layer.
The base system contains a serial I/O interface, a device
controller for SRAM and an SD card, and a clock and reset
signal generator. The SD card controller supports the SPI
mode for read/write operation.
Link Layer.
The link layer contains a simulation synchronizer and a
memory arbiter.
The synchronizer controls the working timing of every im-
plemented function, as shown in Figure.3. In addition, the
synchronizer arbitrates the simulation steps among adjacent
ScalableCore Units. In order to ensure a cycle-accurate sim-
ulation result, each ScalableCore Unit shares the newest data
related to its simulation, such as the output signals of on-chip
routers destined to other routers.
Since the ScalableCore system focuses on tile architectures
consisting of a mesh network, each ScalableCore Unit must
be synchronized with only the four adjacent ScalableCore
Units by sending and receiving the newest data. We refer
to this bound-reduced synchronization as Local Barrier Syn-
chronization.
As shown in Figure.4, in order to move to the next Virtual
Cycle, the synchronizer waits for sending and receiving of
data to be complete by the end of the Virtual Cycle. Since
each of the ScalableCore Units must be synchronized inde-
pendently of the core count of the target processor, the syn-
chronization overhead does not increase when simulating a
processor with a higher core count. It realizes scalable speed
simulation.
In order to obtain the same execution results as the soft-
ware simulator, a synchronizer has the ability to control the
start time of program execution. Figure.5 shows an exam-
ple of program delivery and synchronized start of execution.
In the software simulator, each memory image initialized at
simulation start and all processor cores start execution at the
same time. As described in the following section, each ini-

The memory arbiter selects one function unit accessing the
memory from among the emulated hardware functions, as
shown in Figure.3. Both Core and INCC require two ports
for memory accesses. The memory arbiter chooses and con-
nects address signals and data signals from memory access-
ing units using the Node Memory Controller, which is a local
memory interface.
Base System Layer.
The base system layer contains a memory initializer. The
memory initializer operates when the system is booting and
reads the program binary via the SD controller.
User Layer.
The user layer corresponds to the actual required hardware
components of the target processor.
In ScalableCore system 1.1, the core architecture in the
node is MIPS32 ISA, which is a one-issue single-cycle pro-
cessor. The router is a single cycle router with no virtual
channels. A packet, a group of data with routing informa-
tion, comprises several Ô¨Çits (Flow Control Unit). The Inter-
Node Communication Controller (INCC) sends and receives
both up to 1 Ô¨Çit per cycle. The data width among routers
and between a router and the INCC (network interface) is
8 bits. The local memory interface is realized as a Node
Memory Controller, and the local memory space is allocated
to SRAM via the memory arbiter and SRAM controller, the
size of which is 512 KB.
In order to map complex hardware in the target architec-
ture, they can use multiple FPGA clock cycles, as described
previously of the virtual cycle. All emulated hardware func-
tions have an ‚ÄúEN‚Äù port and a ‚ÄúREADY‚Äù port, which are
input signals to proceed the hardware state and an output
signal to report the completion of the hardware state pro-
ceeding. Synchronizer, a system-controlling unit, uses these
signals to control the emulated hardware processing.
Simulation Phases
The ScalableCore system has two simulation phases, namely,
initialization and running. During the initialization phase,
each ScalableCore Unit recognizes its adjacent units, con-
Ô¨Ågures its ID, and sets the initial memory image of its lo-
cal memory. During the running phase, each ScalableCore
Unit proceeds simulation steps of the target processor core
by taking local barrier synchronization. The following sec-
tions describe the initialization and running phases in detail.
Initialization.
First, the system is powered on, and each unit begins to de-
tect adjacent units (port detection). Each unit sends special
data sequences for port detection to its four neighbors via the
Ser/Des during a certain period. When each unit receives a
certain amount of special data, the unit registers the receiv-
ing port as valid. This information is used for local barrier
synchronizations to wait neighbors‚Äô data.
After port detection, each unit begins to emulate the target
system, with the exception of the processor cores. At the
same time, the upper-left unit (1,1) acquires the initial mem-
ory image from the SD card. The processor core of this unit
then starts to execute the boot-loader program on its local
memory, and the upper-left unit delivers a memory image
to the local memory of each unit by the boot-loader via the
DMA transfer and the implemented NoC as a network of the
target system. If synchronized execution start for all pro-
cessor cores is necessary, then the boot-loader calculates the
start time and notiÔ¨Åes . The upper-left unit then wakes all
processor cores to run via the DMA, and all processor cores
start to execute the loaded program at the start time.
Running.
After the initialization phase, the system moves to the run-
ning phase. Each unit works under the pre-scheduled virtual
cycle. At the end of a virtual cycle, each unit takes a local
barrier synchronization by sending and receiving the newest
value of the interface of emulated hardware functions.
Hardware Implementation
Figure.6 shows a snapshot of the ScalableCore system con-
sisting of 64 (8

ableCore Boards bridging these ScalableCore Units. Fig-

ScalableCore Board.
A ScalableCore Unit is a card-sized FPGA board. The
ScalableCore Unit has a low-capacity FPGA (Xilinx Spartan-
3E XC3S500E), a conÔ¨Åguration ROM (Xilinx XCF04S), a
clock oscillator, and a 512 KB (one-port, 8

SRAM chip. A ScalableCore Unit also has a JTAG port con-

EVALUATION
In this section, we evaluate the developed system with re-
spect to simulation speed and system accuracy.
Simulation Speed
We evaluate the simulation speed of ScalableCore system
1.1 by comparing that of the software simulator. We com-
pared the simulation speed of ScalableCore system 1.1 to
that of the SimMc [13], which is a software-based simula-
tor for M-Core architecture with a functional-level processor
model and a cycle-accurate network on a chip model.
The simulator is run on a standard computer consisting of
a 3.0-GHz Intel Core2Duo E8400 and 4 GB of memory and
is compiled by gcc 4.2.4 (optimization option: -O3). We
measured the speeds of the software simulator and the Scal-
ableCore system for 4 cores, 16 cores, 32 cores, 48 cores,
64 cores, and 100 cores. However, since we have only 64
ScalableCore Units, the speed of the ScalableCore system
obtained for 100 cores is only an estimation. The benchmark
Program is the Equation Solver Kernel [14].
Figure.8(a) shows the simulation speeds of the software
simulator and the ScalableCore system. The X-axis shows
the number of emulated cores, and the Y-axis shows the sim-
ulation speed, which indicates how many target cycles are
emulated per second.
The speed of the software simulator decreases as the num-
ber of cores increases. The software simulator achieves 1,487
K cycles/s and 342 K cycles/s for the simulations using 4
cores and 16 cores, respectively. However, the software sim-
ulator achieved only 70 K cycles/s for the 64 core simulation,
which is one-twentieth that for 4 cores.
The speed of the ScalableCore system is approximately con-
stant at 1,000 K cycles/s for all of the test conÔ¨Ågurations.
This means that the overhead of local barrier synchroniza-
tion is constant. Therefore, the ScalableCore system is scal-
able with respect to core count.
Figure.8(b) shows the speedup rate for the ScalableCore
system as compared to the software simulator. The software
simulator speed decreases as the core count increases. In
contrast, the ScalableCore system speed is constant, so that
the relative speed of the ScalableCore system compared to
the software simulator increases as the number of cores in-
creases. In the 16-core simulation the ScalableCore system
is 2.92 times faster than the software simulator, and in the
64-core simulation the ScalableCore system is 14.2 times
faster than the software simulator. In 100-core simulation,
which provides only an estimated value, the ScalableCore
system is 23 times faster than the software simulator. Thus,
the ScalableCore system has a scale advantage.

System Accuracy
We veriÔ¨Åed the accuracy of the developed system by com-
paring the simulation behavior of the software simulator and
the ScalableCore system, respectively.
RTL vs. Software Simulator
First, we validated the RTL design of the ScalableCore sys-
tem. We conÔ¨Årmed that the architectural behavior of each
emulated processor on the ScalableCore system was equiv-
alent to that of the software simulator for every simulation
step.
In this test, the processor conÔ¨Ågurations are: (1) the num-
ber of cores is up to 16 (4
√ó 4), (2) each core is a MIPS 32
ISA, one-issue, single-cycle processor, (3) each local mem-
ory has 512 KB storage and four access ports (Instruction
fetch, Load/Store, Network Interface Read, and Write), (4)
each router of the NoC is a single-cycle router, warm-hole
router with four input buffers and no virtual channels. The
data width is 8 bits.
The RTL including serial I/Os for local barrier synchro-
nization is tested on the Icarus Verilog 0.9.3 Verilog HDL
simulator. For comparison, we used SimMc which is a soft-
ware simulator.
We compared the following Ô¨Åve characteristics of archi-
tecture states dumped from the software simulator and the
ScalableCore system: (1) Core ID: each core have an identi-
Ô¨Åer for data communication, (2) Cycle Number, (3) Program
Counter, (4) Executed Instruction, (5) Input/Output of Net-
work Interface: a core generates a data packet to another
core via a network interface.
We tested six benchmarks for veriÔ¨Åcation: (a) a single pro-
gram without data communication to/from the other, (b) one-
to-one data communication, (c) one-to-all data communica-
tion, (d) all-to-one data communication, (e) all-to-all data
communication, and (f) Equation Solver Kernel.
As a result, the architecture behavior for each simulation
step matches between the RTL of the ScalableCore system
and the software simulator.
Actual FPGA System vs. Software Simulator
We then compared the execution cycle count to execute a
program on the software simulator and an actual FPGA sys-
tem, respectively. If the execution cycle counts match, the
behavior of the ScalableCore system is the same as that of
the software simulator.
We used the following four benchmarks: (a) a program to
perform noting, (b) one-to-one data communication, (c) par-
allel matrix multiply, and (d) random trafÔ¨Åc communication.
In order for the same conditions to hold, the start of execu-
tion is synchronized for each core in actual FPGA system,
as described in the previous section.
As a result, the execution cycle count of the ScalableCore
system is equal to that of the software simulator.
These results indicate that, as designed, the ScalableCore
system emulates the target architecture in a cycle-accurate
manner.
CONCLUSION
In this paper, we proposed ScalableCore, a concept for re-
alizing a scalable processor simulator for tile architectures.
The ScalableCore system uses local barrier synchronization
and virtual cycle to achieve scalability. ScalableCore sys-
tem 1.1 achieves 14.2 times faster simulation than the corre-
sponding software simulator in 64-core simulation. In addi-
tion, comparing the architecture states and the execution cy-
cle count between the ScalableCore system and the software
simulator conÔ¨Årmed the validity of the proposed system.
In order to achieve higher FPGA utilization and handle
a much greater number of cores, we must consider time-
multiplex techniques similar to those used in other studies.
In addition, in order to emulate more complex hardware func-
tions that are not suitable for single small FPGAs, such as a
wide-issue OoO processor core, we must consider partition-
ing of the hardware into multiple FPGAs.
The current simulation speed is not so fast. In order to ac-
celerate simulations, fast serial I/Os are required for FPGA-
FPGA communications. For more realistic evaluation, we
must develop an off-chip memory model emulator and per-
formance counters.
